  766. The following is quite long and not quite like a typical review. Skip to the last paragraph for the main points if you're not easily entertained. I bought this trimmer almost 2 years ago now. It worked fine for the first month and then suddenly would not hold a charge. I'm fairly knowledgeable when it comes to electronics and battery technology and assumed the battery's safety mechanism got tripped so it would no longer charge. However, with the trimmer plugged in I could get about a minute of use out of it, which was all I needed for the occasional quick touch-up. I wasn't happy, but I dealt with it. Fast forward to a month ago and, out of nowhere, laziness was suddenly overcome by frustration and outrage. I intentionally bought a half-decent trimmer instead of some $10 piece of throw-away technology; why was I accepting this? Of course, this too was built to be disposable technology, as the battery is clearly not intended to be user-serviceable. But I had a purpose now, and (instead of dealing with some warranty procedure) I took a knife to the cheap rubber shrink-wrapped handle and opened the thing up. I know I shouldn't have expected much, but I was surprised at what I found. At the head of the device is a motor about the size of a quarter. In the handle is a PCB about the size of a stick of gum. It contains the switch mechanism and the electronics necessary to charge the battery. The battery, by the way, is a 3.7V 750mAh Li-ion (14500) and is soldered directly to the PCB. A lot of times when companies make disposable electronics like this, they will at least make the battery easy to remove (once you've destroyed the thing by opening it up) so it can be disposed of properly - not here. At this point I was just tempted to throw it away considering the components cost less the amount I was going to spend on a replacement battery (~$2.50). But I figured it could be a simple project that keeps me from having to spend more money on a replacement or dealing with the warranty (which was probably out now that I had taken it apart). I picked up a replacement battery from one of those Chinese online retailers (you know, where you might go if you wanted to find a \\"deal\\" that was \\"extreme\\") and bought a pair of 3.7v 900mAh Li-ions for less than $5 with free shipping. Two weeks later they arrived and I broke out the soldering iron and went to work. The contacts were connected much too securely to the battery, so I melted the solder at the board and just pulled them out. I then took the metal gate off an old 3.5\\" floppy and cut out replacement contacts which I soldered to the new battery. I then punched them back through the trimmer's board, touched them up with a little more solder and snapped the case back together. My only regret was cutting off the rubber sheath, which likely would have peeled off in one piece if I had tried that first. I wrapped it up with some electrical tape instead. Despite the new battery getting pretty hot during some inefficient soldering on my part, it already works at least as good as new. I let the trimmer run for about 10 mins and was satisfied with its performance. The trimmer should have no trouble charging the new battery, as I made sure to splurge on a \\"protected\\" one which should prevent any over-charging or over-draining. Like with the original battery, I'm going to cycle it completely the first few times to condition the battery. During its first charge it's going to sit somewhere fire-resistant just in case. Tl;dr: What's the point? Yeah, this is more of a narrative than a proper review, but there is some good information to be gleaned. Know that this is an extremely cheap piece of electronics. That will be painfully obvious as soon as you pick it up, though it really hits home with a peek inside. Also, realize that it wasn't built to last. Sure it's got a warranty, and at least someone seems enthusiastic to help based on responses to some of the negative reviews, but who reallywants to hassle with the process? The battery will die in probably 1-3 years, just like the one in your cell phone, you just can't replace this one. And, if all you need this for is to trim your sideburns or neck every few weeks, know that you are severely overpaying. You're buying this one for its accessories and maybe because it has a Li-ion battery (though that is my, and a few other commenters', main complaint). And for those of you who read the whole thing, I don't recommend doing what I did, I just shared the steps for entertainment purposes.
  767. The good: a powerful cutter, great battery. The not-so-good: very loud, lots of vibration, throws hair all over the place as it cuts, very cheap plastic snap-on trimmers, limited options in terms of trim length, you need to keep the blades well oiled, not so easy to keep clean. It works, but made me sorely miss my old Norelco Turbo Vacuum Trimmer, so I just gave the Wahl to Goodwill and bought another Norelco Turbo Vac.

  792. I'm very happy with the trimmer but the unit I received does not have an included tray as pictured and indicated in the text of the ad.   793. There are problems with recharging. The cord doesn't seem to work all of the time.
  794. Truly disappointed. I started growing a beard back around November 2014 and by January 2015, had a long, thick beard. I bought these Wahl based solely on my wife swearing by Wahl. She uses their hair cutting kit to trim our son's hair and believe it or not, to groom our two little dogs. I've always known Wahl as a good company, but hadn't used any of their products. I shave my head with a razor so the need for a trimmer really hadn't came up with me before this beard of mine started getting out of control. My belief with these trimmers was I wouldn't use the guards since I have a steady hand and could just slide them down my beard to pick off all the wild hairs. Didn't work. It instead just brushed over them. This caused me to press harder which cost me nearly half of my beard. That's no big deal. It grew back.<br /><br />What was a big deal to me was the build quality of these trimmers. First, the chrome parts on the body feel extremely cheap. The different trimmer heads vary in quality, some feel very sturdy and snap right into place. Others feel cheap and take multiple tries to get them in straight. If you like to feel a trimmer's quality in your hand this isn't the one to get. Maybe the Lithium Ion battery makes it feel so light? Second, the main head it comes with started to rust within the first 5 weeks of owning it. I used them once a week. No possible way for them to have gotten wet either. I ended up buying a pair of Panasonic trimmers that were cheaper and that cut much better.

I would not pay too much over 30$ for this.

I've tried vigorously scrubbing it with a cotton towel which helps a little but then you have cotton particles stuck on there as well. They might as well have just made it out of pure glue its that bad.<br /><br />I get around this, I literally just put masking tape around all of the &#34;black&#34; areas of the clipper which did the job, but certainly not a pretty sight. Overall, i'd say look elsewhere for an easier to clean clipper.

  835. I'll be the first to admit, I ask a lot from any trimmer I purchase. I expect it to trim any/all facial hair with a minimum of pain or discomfort. And to have a &#34;reasonable&#34; life span. That's in quotes because apparently my idea of reasonable life span of 1+ years is excessive.<br /><br />The positive first: During the honeymoon phase (say 2-3 months) everything went great. The charge was pretty good, no discomfort while trimming, and it cleaned up well. There were some minor issues sure, the stand it comes with is largely useless as the moment you brush your hand against it, the whole thing collapses. And the textured handle was difficult to keep clean. But these were minor qualms.<br /><br />After this time, things went from bad to awful. First the battery started dying quicker and quicker. It got to the point where I had to charge the trimmer overnight to ensure that in the morning when I went to trim, it wouldn't die during. Next came the attachment death. First the wide width trimmer broke, then the ear/nose hair trimmer broke. Now I'm down to only the medium width trimmer.<br /><br />As of writing this, I dread having to trim my beard. I have to charge the battery overnight and leave the trimmer plugged in during operation to prevent battery death. No matter how cautious and slow I take it, the blade inevitable will catch and pull hair without cutting. And I'm down to one functional attachment. The &#34;length adjustor.&#34; I mock this because the clip on it slides constantly while I trim, giving one part of my beard &#34;3&#34; length and another part &#34;6&#34; length. As you can imagine, this is frustrating.<br /><br />I have burned through several of these $30-$50 type of trimmers in the last 5 years. Always hoping one or the other will prove to be a winner. No success yet.

  841. I just cracked this thing open and I'm immediately disappointed. I haven't even used yet, but I might not even bother. Here's why: 1) how hard would it be to provide a charging stand? That thing in the picture that looks like a recharging stand, is not a recharging stand. It is just a stand. You'll have to carefully grab the plug and insert it into the bottom of the trimmer, after each time you use it, before setting it in the stand. Why? I don't know. Perhaps they did the math and figured that it would cost them an extra 2.5 cents, and besides, the marketing folks could trick us into thinking that the pretty stand in the picture was a charging stand. Whatever, I'm bugged. 2) This product requires oil. Unlike 90% of the other trimmers out there, which do not require any oil at all, this one must be oiled on a regular basis. Don't oil it and it will freeze up within a week. Which means that after a year, when I run out of oil, I will probably be throwing this thing away. Yet another inconvenience with this product. Most other trimmers can simply be used over and over again with no maintenance. Not this one. It is the Fiat of beard trimmers. 3) That stand is a mess. Who wants to have all that stuff sitting on their counter? Bathrooms get dusty and the dust in a bathroom gets moisture, which means that all those combs, brushes and everything else will need cleaning. All 20 of them. They could have provided a little housing for all this stuff, so as to protect them from the bathroom's environment, but nope. Not Wahl. They obviously don't use their own products. This product won't last a year. In fact it might not last a day because I'm think of getting rid of it today.
  842. Product: Wahl L-ion All In One Trimmer<br />Rating: 3 1/2 stars<br /><br />It's better than I expected, but not problem free.<br /><br />Likes:<br />------<br />* POWER: I've always leaned towards trimmers using rechargrable AAs, but when I went to replace my last trimmer only to discover it'd been discontinued, I picked the Wahl. I've been using it for almost a month now, and it's still on the original charge. Speed and power are both excellent. Recharge time is apparently very fast too.<br /><br />* SHARPNESS: This is by far the sharpest electric trimmer I've ever tried. I have a very tough beard, and the Wahl glides through it effortlessly.<br /><br />Dislikes:<br />--------<br />* ATTACHMENT OVERLOAD: This model comes with far more attachments than most people are ever likely to use. I wish they'd unbundled most of them into an optional expanded attachments set, because the only attachment I want or need is the adjustable depth trimmer guide.<br /><br />* ADJUSTABLE TRIMMER HEAD: Although it works fine, it has some quirks. First is that it takes two hands to alter the setting, or to remove and reattach it ... and because it's a clip-on-top, rather than a fully enclosed attachment, you have to be careful around folds and wrinkles, to avoid getting nicked, especially on a shallow setting. That's one feature I miss about my old trimmer ... the fully enclosed adjustable guide head.<br /><br />Bottom line: although I dislike all the attachments, the trimmer itself is excellent. Recommended.

I hope they continue making this model in the future.<br /><br />I use the trimmer once a week to shave my head and the charge on lithium ion battery lasts for couple months on a single charge. The motor is powerful but the trimmer is very compact and comfortable in my hand. The black rubber on the handle is not slippery so you can hold it securely without worrying about it slipping off your hands. The blades are fine and precise but the cutting path is slightly narrower than my full size trimmers.<br /><br />What else can I say? If this one breaks down, I will definitely buy this product again.<br />In the future, I would like to see a larger (XL) option of this same product. But, for those who travel, this trimmer is outstanding; compact, powerful, and lightweight and it works right.<br /><br />One improvement suggestion for future model is the trimmer needs a charge level indicator light. I would pay $10 extra for that feature.<br /><br />Note; I see some people complain about noise and vibration, I have owned many trimmers and they all are noisy, and vibrate. That's how trimmers function. I feel this trimmer is more comfortable than all other trimmers I owned and I have owned multiple models from Phillips-Norelco, Braun, Remington, Wahl, Oster.

The battery life on this trimmer is also excellent. I have used it once to trim, shave, cut and put it away only for it to still have good battery life a few weeks later. For those that complain about the nose attachment, I can't use it anyways because the vibrations make it impossible, I recommend cutting those hairs the old fashion way, scissors.   868. l have previously owned two Philips Norelco cordless groomers and had disappointing experiences with both. One was the [[ASIN:B000U65ZPE Philips Norelco BG2022 Bodygroom, Limited Edition]] and the other a [[ASIN:B000FEF1V4 Philips Norelco T980 Turbo Vacuum Trimmer]]. They both started off just fine, but in both cases the batteries failed shortly after their warranties expired. Batteries in these little groomers cannot be replaced (at least not without a soldering iron and some technical know how) so when they go, you're stuck buying a replacement. I did some homework before selecting a replacement and there were several reasons why I selected this Wahl model.<br /><br />1. Wahl is the #1 choice of professional barbers. I figure that if it's good enough for a pro, it's plenty good for me.<br />2. This Wahl product uses a lithium battery, not the older nickel-cadmium battery technology.<br />3. This Wahl is made in the USA (Illinois) and I want to support domestic manufacturing whenever it's a competitive option.<br />4. It comes with all of the attachments I might ever need for my intended use.<br />5. It is competitively priced and has lots of positive reviews.<br /><br />Some reviews talk about this coming in some sort of a plastic stand and how that stand isn't sturdy enough. I can imagine what they're describing because I had those little plastic organizers with some of the other like-products I've owned. I never liked them because they were always a bit flimsy/tippy and mainly because I don't want my trimmer to be on display on my bathroom vanity anyway. I guess if a guy sports facial hair and reaches for this product on a near daily basis the plastic organizer might be important. But in my case, this gets used maybe once weekly at the most and I just toss it in a drawer after use. But at any rate, it's a moot point as mine didn't ship with that plastic organizer anyway. Mine came with a zippered bag that holds all of the trimmer pieces and the power cord. I like this as it keeps all the parts together and is easy to store in a bathroom vanity drawer.<br /><br />The battery life on this trimmer has been phenomenal. I charged it per the instructions when it first arrived and haven't had to charge it again once since then (about a month as of this writing). This trimmer does everything I need it to do and I am really glad I went with this Wahl model.eps all the parts together and is easy to store in a bathroom vanity drawer. The battery life on this trimmer has been phenomenal. I charged it per the instructions when it first arrived and haven't had to charge it again once since then (about a month as of this writing). This trimmer does everything I need it to do and I am really glad I went with this Wahl model.

The base was fine though and worked fine with the few heads I hadn't lost yet. Replacement heads are available from WAHL for $7.50, $5.95 shipping and $4 handling. At that point I've bought half of a new unit so I elected to just buy a 2nd. I'll have a full set of heads this way, 2 bases, and a bag to store it all in so I won't lose anything else moving forward.<br /><br />The unit absolutely powers through hair. I didn't realize how well it did until I had to revert back to my old unit to get by until I could replace this one. The old Conair chewed on my thick beard, barely cutting it. The WAHL never had that problem. My beard kept getting stuck between the Conair's trimmer and the plastic guard. That was never a problem with the WAHL. I can't wait until my replacement comes in later this week because No Shave November needs to get mowed down!   885. I was trying to decide between this Trimmer and the 9818. Although I can't really complain about this one, I wish I'd gone with the other. The main reason I went with this one was for the shave attachment as that is what I use my trimmer for (not as close as a razor, but good enough for my needs). Unfortunately, that attachment isn't very good at all. I don't use it. The main blade is also very uncomfortable on my face (I don't use any of the attachments on my face, try to get as close a shave as possible). This is less of an issue, because the T Blade is comfortable enough to use, and since it's larger, it's actually a bit faster to shave.<br /><br />The biggest problem with this trimmer is the rubberized handle. I have no idea how this thing got through any testing in the Wahl company, but I hope the people responsible for this ingenious idea have been removed from a position of power. Your facial hair WILL stick to this thing. Any &#34;comfort&#34; you get from having a rubber handle instead of a metal one is totally negated by all the hair that gets stuck to the handle.<br /><br />All that being said, the blades are good, give a nice shave and overall I'm perfectly content with this trimmer. But if you're trying to decide between this and the 9818, I'd go with that one instead. From what I've read, it's a better trimmer and doesn't have these small nuisances.
  886. The idea of Interchangeable heads is great but dont get the Idea just because it is Lithium Ion Battery that is has alot of power but inorder for trimmers to be effective it takes RPMs which move the cutting blades back and forth I am not sure if its because of the interchangeable head set up but the blade movements are not what they should be to be overall effective, it works but plan on a few hair pulls
  887. Like everything about this product, have had no problems with it since I purchased it about 6 months ago.<br /><br />I would highly recommend getting this product for those who wish to maintain their beard, or to even shave.
  888. I have had a full beard and moustache since 1978. Over the years I have tried various scissors and clippers to keep it trimmed. This trimmer is by far the best I have ever used. It holds a charge for a long time and it trims without missing. I prefer having the small pouch to keep it in along with all of the attachments. I have had clippers that have a &#34;base&#34; to hold them with the attachments. That always ends up getting in the way on my bathroom counter. I have had clippers that were cheaper but they never trim as well and quickly wear out.<br /><br />I read many reviews before buying this. I saw comments about it pulling hair. It will pull hair if used incorrectly. There are two ways to hold the trimmer when using. One way is (1) to put the flat side of the clipper head parallel to the skin and the other is (2) to put the flat side of the clipper head perpendicular to the skin. Using method (2) can pull hair and using method (1) has never pulled hair on me.<br /><br />I would clearly buy this item again and would recommend it to anyone.

  900. I'VE REVISED MY REVIEW BECAUSE OF WAHL'S EXCELLENT CUSTOMER SERVICE......THEY'VE ADDRESSED THE ISSUE. My original review is at the bottom of this entry. I received a message from a Wahl representative to told me to call them and they would help me. I called. What I learned is that there are two 'levels' of product; professional and home use. This product is more for home use (i.e. a guy trimming his beard). The professional product to which I was accustomed (The Peanut) is intended for the heavy/constant use in a salon setting. They offered me a refund and informed me that, due to the Wahl warranty, I could mail my broken Peanut for repair at a cost of only $15. I'm thrilled. Thank you, CT and Wahl. ------------------------------------------------------------------------- ORIGINAL REVIEW: I usually use a PEANUT trimmer (corded) to clip my Yorkie's face and ears. Mine broke and this looked like a great option for replacement because it's cordless. Problem is, it doesn't trim very well at all. I have to go over and over the same spot and the results are still ragged.

  916. It worked reasonably well while it worked. The trimmer head is very narrow, which makes it harder to get an even trim on the beard, but the mini-shaver had works very well for trimming around the beard. Unfortunately, it's built to fail.<br /><br />Mine lasted 14 months, and then stopped dead in the middle of a trim. The battery was charged, and the unit didn't slow down as if the battery were dying. One second it was working fine, the next it was dead.<br /><br />I took it apart to see if it was repairable, but it appears to be the motor that failed. Worse yet, the construction quality is pretty much junk. There's no effort to seal the unit, so the electronics were covered with fine hair residue. And almost all of the plating had worn off the switch contacts. Even if the motor hadn't failed, the switch probably wouldn't last to the two year mark.<br /><br />Wahl used to be known for high-quality, rugged trimmers. But it appears they've embraced planned obsolescence. No more Wahl products for me..
  917. Only used it once, then it died. I then dropped it from about 4&#34; above counter and the whole head broke off. Maybe you get what you pay for? Not an is to last long.

  919. I bought this trimmer at my local store and paid $45 for it, Amazon is offering a much better price ($32 as of this review), but it doesn't change the fact that this trimmer is still not worth the price. I didn't use all the attachments and I primarily bought this to keep hair neat in between trips to the barber.<br /><br />PROS:<br /><br />- Price<br />- Li-ion battery charges fast<br />- Trimmer blade is great for detailing, goes around ears easily<br />- Lots of attachments/accessories<br /><br />CONS:<br />- Blades rust easily<br />- Worthless eyebrow/nose/ear attachment<br />- Handle attracts hair, dirt, dust, you name it<br />- Accessory stand is cheap - stuff falls out of it frequently<br /><br />The basic trimmer function works great, and the build quality of the blade LOOKS nice, but it isn't. I never got the blades wet, but as other reviewers noted, the blade RUSTED QUICKLY. How this happened, I have no idea, I'm assuming some sweat got on there. I oiled the blades and cared for them as instructed, and it still rusted - in a couple months! This has never happened to me with other trimmers from Wahl or any other brand.<br /><br />I was pretty excited about the precision detailer attachment because I'm tired of having a bunch of grooming tools in my bathroom. As some other people said, the precision detailer attachment was completely worthless. I thought I would use it to get some straggling hairs around my eyebrows, and I had to make several passes before it would cut the hairs off - unevenly and not closely. It also did a horrible job trimming my nose hair - it pulled on the hairs and hardly cut anything. I ended up having to fall back on my old Philips Norelco groomer anyway.<br /><br />Some other reviewers had a different experience, but for me, the dual foil shaver was NOT good for shaving facial hair. Even being very careful and following instructions, the dual foil shaver still irritated my skin and left a bunch of stubble behind - after that happened, I ONLY used it to pick up a couple stray hairs below my sideburns that the trimmer blade didn't get the first time around. I have sensitive skin, but I've never had a foil shaver irritate my face like that.<br /><br />The lithium ion battery is not over-hyped. It charges quickly and holds a charge well. I only had to charge it once a week at the most. The accessory stand is worthless, it only held the main unit securely, everything else fell out and created clutter. Ended up having to put unused parts in a ziploc bag. Again, as others said, the handle attracts everything (namely hair, dust). I used a damp cloth to wipe it clean, but even the fibers from the cloth somehow got stuck on the handle. The material feels nice when you hold it, but looks messy and is a little annoying to keep clean.<br /><br />Overall, in terms of its basic function, the trimmer blade works great at trimming neck hair, sideburns, over-ear hair, etc. However, the blades are of questionable quality and mine rusted quickly. This is being marketed as an \\"All-in-One Trimmer\\" and it is not. Prior to this, I had big corded Wahl clippers that lasted 10+ years before they broke, so I had a good impression of their products. I really like that Wahl still manufactures most of their products in the USA and I really wanted to like this trimmer, but unfortunately, it didn't work out.

I do not &#34;hate it&#34; because it broke and is now useless, as things brake from time to time and I do have a very thick beard. I hate it because it is very messy to use as a lot of hair will stick to the handle, too much IMO. I used this in the shower, before turning the water on, so that the clippings will be washed away when I do take a shower. However, so much hair will stick to the handle that I had to use the toothbrush to clean it in the sink and then clean the sink. Too much trouble, very bad design! The only &#34;pro&#34; I have for this is that the battery would last a fairly long time, I only had to charge it once or twice in the couple of months that it worked properly.   940. Bought this at a local store and couldn't have been more disappointed. The only positive thing I can say for this product is that the lithium battery does last for a long time.   951. I have had so many electric shavers that it's become a joke with my wife. Once they start pulling hair or the battery won't charge, I'll say \\"I guess it's time for a new razor\\", to which she responds, \\"Well, it's been a couple of months.\\"<br /><br />I think that's going to change with this razor. I absolutely love this razor and look forward to using it because of how good of a job it does. I like alternating between stubble beard to goatee. I also shave my head and groom from head to toe and everywhere in-between. This is the first razor I can honestly say does it all for me.<br /><br />Largest Blade: Shaving my head and neck takes 1/2 the time with the larger head than it used to with my other razors. It has a very smooth back and slices the hair off with no tug and pull.<br /><br />Smaller Blade: This is great for outlining my beard. The larger blade could do it, but I feel like I have more control. I also use this with the adjustable guards for various lengths. I love the fact that some of the attachments are one size. I get WAAAAAY better results this way instead of the generic 10 dial adjuster other razors come with.<br /><br />Smallest Blade: A lot of reviews I read say this trimmer, mainly for ears/nose/eyebrows, doesn't work well. They must have some course, thick hair because I've never had a trimmer that works this well. I didn't expect much out of this trimmer based on the reviews, so I'm pleasantly surprised.<br /><br />Foil Shaver: I've had several of these in the past, and they all break me out almost as if I used a real razor. I have used this on my face, my neck, my chest, and the cash-n-prizes... not one bit of irritation. You have to go over it several times to get a smooth feel and it can be a little noisy, but every one of these type of razors I've had were that way. So for this to work as well as it does as an attachment makes me happy.<br /><br />--------<br /><br />Cons:<br />- The attachments (blades mentioned above) can be pretty tricky toput on and take off at first. I sometimes felt as if I could break one at any moment. Now, I'm used to them and pop them on and off.<br /><br />- The stand is acceptable, but I didn't really have room for everything. I spent about 15 minutes trying to figure out what went were because not all of the pieces fit. I've got it all worked out now.<br /><br />- The blades can get pretty hot and the smallest blade and foil shaver can get a little noisy. They work great, so I overlook it.<br /><br />--------<br /><br />Tip:<br /><br />- Some people's reviews complain about the rubber grip holding hair that's been shaven. This is absolutely true. However, all you have to do is take a wet cloth, wrap it around the rubber grip, and pull down. The hair will come off with no problem at all.<br /><br />--------<br /><br />Conclusion: I love this razor! It has a five year warranty, it's pretty cheap, and feels like a sturdy razor that will last a long time. I highly recommend.

  966. This is a great little trimmer. I already owned a similar trimmer made by Remmington, but this new WAHL trimmer completely trumps the Remington in performance. When I got it out of the box I was thrilled to see it already had a pretty substantial charge and was ready to go. Immediately I noticed that this trimmer has a ton of torque which I attribute to the Lithium Ion battery. This is very important because if you've ever used a battery powered nose trimmer when the battery is going, you KNOW that when the battery starts to go, hair gets pulled instead of cut. I tried the foil shaver attachment... it actually did a surprisingly decent job and I typically hate foil shavers. I'm still not convinced that it will replace my old school manual razor for shaving, but it's a good quick option. Pros: - Powerful! - Charges fast and runs long. - Easy to switch attachments. - Made in USA. (a rare find these days) - Built like a tank. Cons: - Alot of pieces to keep track of. - Flimsy organizer tray (but I don't use it anyways) - My old Remington had an adjustable blade guard so you didn't have a half dozen pieces laying around. - Rubber grip attracts hair stubble. Update: After using this trimmer for a few months I would have to knock it down a star. This trimmer is NOT in any way water resistant. On a couple occasions I would rinse the hair out of the blades and then leave it out to dry. The trimmer blades will get rust very quickly. I then went to use the trimmer the other night and it would not turn on. I proceeded to take it apart and found that the internal circuit board had corrosion across some of the leads to the various chips. I took an old toothbrush and removed all the corrosion and it began working again. To ensure this never happened again I coated all the metal contacts with hot glue to keep out the water. WAHL, what were you thinking? This thing will set by the sink for it's entire life, and you put absolutely no thought into resisting corrosion? You could have coated the PCB in epoxy, or sealed the internals. I was able to fix mine, but the average person probably would have just thrown it away.
  967. All in one solutions help simply our life. Why get more than one item when one does the trick. However sometimes there is a trade off. Such is unfortunately the case with the Wahl Lithium Ion All in one Trimmer, while having a large assortment of attachments, each on only half completes its task. For example the trimmer and the shaver barley succeed at doing the same job other razors do that are dedicated to the task. If you need something quick for travel I would recommend getting this trimmer. However if you are looking for daily use I would get one dedicated to the task you are trying to do.
  968. This is a pretty decent trimmer kit that is capable of all basic facial hair managment. The trimmer was already charged and ready to go out of the box. The different head types (standard for trimming down facial hair, wide for haircuts, narrow for nose and precision requirements, and twin foil for a smooth shave) are great and can be interchanged fairly easily. The downsides are the difficulty of physically adjusting the adjustable guard attachment and a big one for me is the material of the handle. Though the handle is comfortable to hold, hair and skin flakes stick to it and is almost near impossible to clean off. All in all, a very handy trimmer in a small package.
  969. This trimmer worked well for the first 6 months then it died and would no longer turn on. Disappointing that it only lasted 6 months of light use a few time a week.
  970. This is about the fourth trimmer I've had in my life and I'd rate this Wahl Lithium Ion Trimmer about AVERAGE (see update below). The main unit gets the job done and has a decent motor, but the comb attachments, foil shaver and organizer are very cheap and don't function well. Another reviewer mentioned how impressed they were with the foil shaver attachment. I very much disagree. I've attempted to use it twice (once wet/once dry) and it doesn't even cut through my beard. I'm not sure if my beard hairs are too coarse or what the problem is, but I ended up just throwing the foil shaver away. I also threw the cheap plastic stand/organizer away. Pathetic a company like Wahl would include something like that with their product. I have no need for the included plastic comb attachments, but I tried to put them on and turn on the unit to see how they performed. I agree with some of the reviewers below. They don't fit snug against the blades and seem like they could easily break. Finally, getting the various attachments on/off the main unit isn't easy (especially with wet hands/fingers). You won't spend 10 mins. trying to attach them, but it will take 20 or 30 seconds of repeatedly trying to line up the internal parts.<br /><br />In sum, I would not purchase this trimmer if you have need of the various plastic attachments/organizer/foil shaver. But if all you are looking for is an average trimmer this will suffice. I don't believe it is worth $30-$40, however. Other companies have trimmers in the $14-$21 range that will work just as well.<br /><br />UPDATE (1 month later)- This thing is a piece of garbage! The battery does not stay charged for more than an hour (of non-use) and in the last three days the unit has stopped responding to the On/Off button. It doesn't work anymore. I'm calling Wahl customer service tomorrow to see what can be done. Worst trimmer I've ever purchased. Sorry, but that's the truth.
  971. Rock solid. Don't mess with the others. You will know the second you turn it on its quality.
  972. love it use it all the time

This lead to the purchase of this new Wahl, which outperforms it's older counterparts. While it is a lighter weight than the older one, it provides superior performance so far.   979. Had one of these for 5 years. It finally died after my kids dropped it over 50 times. It worked so well I replaced it with the same thing!
  980. I only use this to trim my beard so I can't speak to the function of the shaver. I was pleased with how quickly this shipped and the price that I paid for the quality of the product. It holds a charge for what seems like forever and is easy to clean. I am pleased and would recommend it.
  981. We are very happy withis purchase, excellent quality and a great shaver for the price. My husband said this is one of the best he has ever had for a shaver. all the attachments are great too.
  982. This is exactly what he needed, and he seemed to like it. Nice to give something other than video game related things !!!!!
  983. This foil razor gave a surprisingly close shave. The attachments are a nice addition. Good value for the money. The only drawback is the not so ergonomic shape of the shaver, otherwise, 5 stars.
  984. The trimmer is very nice and works perfectly and is powerful. The battery lasts quite long between charges (I used it about 10 times and did not need to charge it so far). I love the trimmer.<br /><br />However:<br />Most of the accessories are useless (the only one I use is one of the combs to protect the blade when not in use...), and I would have traded all of them against a better charging function.<br /><br />There is no charging indicator (no indication that it is charging and no indication that the battery is full), the charging is totally open loop (plug, leave for a few hours and hope it is charged).<br />Also the wall brick is not a standard power brick, but is actually the charger itself (4.2V output = Full voltage of a Lithium battery). It seems they saved the cost of a charging regulator in the trimmer. So in case you lose the wall-brick, don't try to replace it with a 5V USB brick, I suppose that you can destroy the battery.<br />The charger is also 110V only (while most of the countries are using 220V now and a battery powered shaver is likely to be used for travelers...)<br /><br />In summary: a very nice trimmer showing that Wahl's engineering is good and they know how to make good products. But I think that Wahl's Marketing is not, and did some wrong choices about cost saving of the charger. I think it would have made more sense to decrease the amount of accessories and use the saved money for a better charging function and standard auto-ranging wall-brick.
  985. All attachments work great. Holds a charge for a long time.
  986. I used this trimmer two times before it broke. Just stopped working all together. I guess you get what you pay for.
  987. I like this product due to its many attachments for different hair lengths. When I was first shopping around for a new beard trimmer, I had no idea what to look for, so the top rated product on Amazon was a Philips-norelco brand beard trimmer at the time. I had remembered that I had previously had a terrible experience with my Philips-norelco rechargeable razor, and also remembered that my Wahl Chrome Pro Clipper set has far exceeded my expectations, so I went with Wahl just from my previous experiences, and could not be happier. This unit is rechargeable, and comes with a handy-dandy little station to hold all the attachments and the razor itself. This one product is really all you need to remain a well-groomed and distinguished man. :)<br /><br />Bottom Line: Awesome trimmer, only downside that SOME people may see is that it does not have a vacuum system. I however, do not care.
  988. They fail to mention that this is a 'disposable' device. I have had two of them. After about 18-24 months the battery dies and that is to be expected. The problem is that the battery is soldered to the circuit board via two clips and is NOT replaceable. Because it is a Lithium battery it needs to disposed of in an environmentally responsible manner. I am now looking for a replacement --- a WIRED replacement.

  1007. I tried 4 different models of cordless, all-in-one trimmers before settling on this unit, so I do have plenty of first-hand experience with this product and its competitors. If you can find it for under $30, don't think twice and buy it (I found this unit advertised at a large electronics superstore for just under $20 after buying my 4th all-in-one cordless trimmer from a large deparment store that has a 110% price guaranty, so I really found a bargain). The powerplant in this model (Lithium vs. the older NiCad or NiMH rechargables) makes this the one to beat against all others in the sub-$60 price-range. The Lithium battery, and related power output is its best feature. I used it daily as my shaver for 10 days straight, plus gave myself and my thick-furred dog a buzz-cut before I noticed any change in the power output... straight out of the box! My dog's hair is the thickest of any hair, located anywhere on any mammal on the Earth, so when this unit made easy work of his steel-wool mayne, I bragged it up to my three brothers and each one bought this model (when it was on sale for one weekend in November). Our wives/girlfriends of course requested a man-scapeing session right away, and it passed that test with flying colors (and no nicks, scrapes or scratches... whew!) So ladies and gents, don't waste your time with the older-technology rechargeables no matter how amazing the blades are or how many toys it comes with. Go cordless, go lithium and go home to a well-groomed human, rather than an unruly sasquatch (unless that \\"Bear\\" look is your thing). Great product!
  1008. My experience is pretty good in this trimmer. The batery least long time without have to charge again. I shave once a week and it least like 3 months. Me machine is loud, but works good. I recomend it. The accesories are interesting.

  1010. I've waited a long while to write this--two years--because electronic items often don't last a long time and/or they work well at first and then crap out. This item is well worth the money; indeed, for my money, it's the best of its kind on the market (and now I see that Amazon is selling it for even less than I paid for it!). It charges quickly, and it holds a full charge a looooong time. In sum, it does what it's suppose to do and does it well. If there's one \\"negative\\" aspect to this model, it's the rubber handle that seems to attract cut hair (due to static build-up), but it cleans off easily with a light brush. This product was worth every penny I paid for it.

  1024. I use this sort of trimmer for everyday shaving. I have been doing this for many years and I have burned through more trimmers than I would care to recall. I have always bought wireless trimmers, and have always ended up having to keep them plugged in. This is the first trimmer I have ever bought where this is not the case. The lithium Ion allows me to use this trimmer for 5-10 minutes every morning for more than a week in between charges, AND the motor does not become noticeably less powerful as the charge goes down.<br /><br />The accessories are so-so. I don't think I would use this for anything other than shaving, beard trimming, or doing light maintenance on my hair. This is not a full sized Wahl trimmer so do not expect to open up a salon with this thing. However, if you use it for what it was designed for or what I use it for you shouldn't have any issues. With that in mind, pretty much all of the accessories are useless for my purposes. The plastic guards seem to be good quality but I wont be cutting my own hair so I can't verify that. The two metal trimmer attachment (one small one a little larger) work well and are sharp and smooth. The included shaving attachment look ok, but I will never use it. The precision trimming attachment works well. It also comes with a junky miniature comb, a good cleaning brush and a small amount of oil.<br /><br />Overall this is a solid piece of equipment for what it does and what it costs, this thing is probably the best at what it does, hands down.<br /><br />PROS-<br />Solidly built<br />great motor<br />Li-ion batteries are your friend<br />1-2 weeks of usage per charge<br />Some good attachment<br /><br />CONS-<br />the stand is kinda junky<br />some of the attachments are useless
  1025. I bought this to replace a less expensive Wahl trimmer, and I'm not thrilled. Some of the guards and blades cause the razor to pull and rip at whiskers instead of shaving them off. This may be the razor that convinces me -- after twelve years -- to return to a blade and shaving cream.
  1026. I purchased this since shaving was irritating, and i dont like the way i look with a fresh shave.<br /><br />I like using this product without any attachments, just the trimmer. I use this every other day before work, it lets me keep a light beard (sporadic since my facial hair hasn't decided to fully grow out at the age of 27). It comes with my many attachments, but like other reviewers, i find them cheap and almost pointless.<br /><br />THINGS TO KNOW:<br />this does come with small bottle of blade lube, and i recommend using it. about once a month or 6 weeks i put 1 drop of the lube on the blade and turn on the trimmer so it spreads across all \\"teeth\\". If you use a drop or 2 every 6 months there is enough to last a few years. i also noticed that the trimmer seemed to get louder as i used it, BUT after lubing it 1 time it brought the noise down and keeps it smooth.<br /><br />I also use the little comb/brush to brush my hairs out of the trimmer after every use, i think the oils from the hair can wear out the trimmer quicker, which means having it to lube it more frequently.<br /><br />the battery last me around 2 weeks, with 3 trims per week. i probably have it on for a bout 3-4 minutes per trim. from sideburns to neck to mustache. i have owned it for at least 6 months with no issues. i only charge it when i can tell it start to slow down, usually over night.<br /><br />the bad:<br />the tray sucks, its way too light and cheap, i couldn't even figure out how all the pieces were suppose to fit in it. i like the super rubber grip of the trimmer, but if you pull it from the tray to quick it will just pull the tray with it and all the pieces will go flying everywhere. so i just put all the extra in a zip lock bag and stuck them under the sink. i keep the trimmer and brush/comb in the nearest drawer and your good to go.<br /><br />Overall:<br /><br />I use this all the time, it seems to last a while and i haven't had any problems. i wouldnt use it for eyebrows or nose(Norelco NT9110/60 is the bomb for that). If you want something to keep your beard short (not shaven) then this will work, and well. just take care of it, lube and charge accordingly (only when needed). you will be happy with the results.

  1045. Nice trimmer setup, easy to use and change over from one setup to another.   1047. After reading a few reviews I was a little iffy on what to expect. I've had the trimmer now for about two months and its great. It's everything that I wanted in a trimmer.<br />The pluses on the trimmer is it cuts hair pretty close to the skin. The teeth on the cutter head do not get caught in my pores/hair falical like other trimmers I've had. I don't know how long the battery lasts but I only charge it once a week and there is still stronge battery life before I put it in a charge. The trimmer hair guides work very well<br />Although they're some downsides. If you wanted to use the trimmer for your nose it will be a little difficult. The head attachment for nose trimming is flat and not really designed for that use. Also the rubber grip attracts hair very well and sticks. I found that a cheap 30 cent toothbrush removed it fairly easy.<br />All in all the trimmer is great and I would recommend it to anybody who was looking for a bang for your buck trimmer
  1048. used it the very night i got it came precharged and it shaped me just right lol now I don't have to go pay someone else to do it
  1049. Had high expectations for this trimmer...it did not meet them.<br /><br />Pros: Lithium power. I have no idea why lithium trimmers are not more common; the battery keeps a charge for a very long time, recharges fast, and has plenty of power. Blades do cut well.<br /><br />Cons: first off, this thing HURTS! From day one it was very difficult to trim without nicking myself with the blades. I got used to holding them a certain way to minimize injuries, but after using other trimmers and not having to be so careful during normal use, this one can only be described as mildly dangerous at best...especially if used in sensitive areas (get my drift?).<br /><br />Also, the blades began to rust almost right away. Even when following the oiling & cleaning instructions, rust began to appear after only a couple of uses. This did not really impede the item's functioning, but with the constant nicking this thing causes, having the risk of cutting myself with a rusty blade every time I trimmed was not fun.<br /><br />I'm the type to use a product until it dies, so I will say that this trimmer lasted me over a year before the main blade finally cracked & broke. I replaced it with a Philips Norelco QG3360/42 Multigroom Plus and was VERY pleased. The Phillips model shaves so smooth & easy that a baby could use it. I should have returned this Wahl and replaced it earlier.<br /><br />Overall, the lithium battery is all this model has going for it, and that ain't enough. try the Phillips instead...you'll thank me.

It now only runs for maybe 1-2 minutes, and even noticeably slows down even during that time. The run time is barely enough to clip half a leg now. To be fair, my trimmer is pretty old, maybe 5 years, and I've just sucked it up and lived with it even though it's been getting worse and worse since there does not appear to be any way for the user to change batteries on this thing.<br /><br />However, the battery is not the worst part - the little cheap plastic &#34;depth guides&#34; have prongs that are too far apart and this thing does not control the hair length worth doo-doo. I constantly get &#34;bare spots&#34; where the hair is essentially clipped right at the skin, or just barely above. It looks terrible. A clipper has ONE job to do, and that is to cut the hair at length you want. This fails miserably at that. No matter how slow or carefully I control the pressure and the angle, I always get a &#34;surprise&#34; during every session where I get &#34;balded&#34;. This effect happens particularly badly with the short guide (3mm) though I have gotten &#34;balded&#34; by the 6mm one as well.<br /><br />The hand unit seems well made, but...<br />The battery sucks terribly.<br />The hair length guides cannot be trusted.<br /><br />In short. Reviews said that the Wahl battery was easily replaceable and the motor was strong, so I went for it. I've been using it for several months, and here are my thoughts. There are way too many parts. They are difficult to put on and take off. Intuitiveness does not come into play here. The device is difficult to clean. Very difficult. Hovering around impossible. And how does it work? You have to hold it very carefully at a precise angle for it to cut properly. But the motor is strong and the battery has given me no problems. For a beard and extraneous hair cutter, it works adequately. However, I dread having to use it, and I think that I won't wait for the replaceable battery to wear out before I get another Norelco.

  1152. Wahl has typically been a trustyworthy name, that's one reason I went with this line. This particular trimmer is Lithium-Ion (Li-Ion), and that means a long time between charges. The motor is plenty powerful, the trimer selections are quite inclusive for most anyone's beard, moustache, complex goattee. I currently sport a Van Dyke, which needs careful grooming since my beard comes in heavy, with no thin spots. That's where the smallest of the trimmer heads is supreme. This trimmer is approximately 3/8\\" wide, so it'll let you cut a distinct edging to your fur. Granted, you'll have to use a safety razor to get the stubble, but this outfit will groom the \\"man hedge\\" just fine. So far, I'm pleased. The beard \\"combs\\" allow you to keep the length nice and even in depth, and the actual shaver head isn't too bad either, although I use a safety razor for that, since one has to come right up to the Van Dyke to keep a clean edge, and most electric razors won't get that task done easily. The only other thing I'd mention, is that one has to be very careful when putting on the trimmer heads, as it is a bit tricky, and the parts could break if you're a troglodyte about it. Caveat brutus.
  1153. This has been a great product. Stays charged for months on end!
  1154. I purchased this trimmer to replace another Wahl trimmer that I purchased 6-7 years ago. I have to say that this trimmer cuts much closer than the older one. I'm very satisfied with this product. My other Wahl trimmer has lated many years, and it's still working. And I'm confident this one will last just as long.
  1155. As other people have mentioned, there is a major problem with the battery on this thing. We bought this trimmer in April and it's now October and the battery won't hold a charge anymore. This won't be a big deal since we have a very convenient outlet in our bathroom. However, the power connection is so crappy that it won't even charge at all. Additional the blades rusted quickly.
  1156. Well made, had many options for lengths. The charge lasts a long time. Better than any other of the cordless trimmers I've purchased.

  1184. I had another Wahl trimmer for many years. The battery had finally conked out, so I ordered another one. This thing is great. I use the trimmer only for trimming sideburns and hairline on my neck, so I really don't need the other accessories it comes with, and the base is just inconvenient, though it looks good in the picture.   1192. I see lots of reviews for this junky trimmer, and it won't matter much to its overall rating, but I must add my two cents. Steer clear of this god-awful product. Oh, the instruction booklet was intricately detailed on its trimming uses, but not on how to utilize the convoluted combs relative to the attachments, which no longer fit adequately nor stay in place for any of the combinations I attempt. Argh!! The booklet might as well have been written in hieroglyphics. Useless, in the end. Now the blades have also dulled to uselessness, despite the \\"self-sharpening\\" claim, and it painfully pulls hairs and generally drives me nuts. The warranty is pointless, too, as you would either receive the returned trimmer repaired, or get a replacement....another crummy Wahl trimmer, in both cases. Oh, boy! The museum reference pertains to my reverence for junk products, everywhere. It's a museum piece, to be put away in a 'Chamber of Horrors of Consumer Goods' exhibit, where it can never inflict its pain again!

My father used a Wahl to cut my hair as a kid more years ago than I care to admit and I've been using this to trim my beard for the last few years and I really like it.<br /><br />It's a quality product and other than the battery which will eventually die, I would buy it again and again.
  1196. really does a nice job comes with many adapters charges quick everything about this piece is really good . I am very pleased with this!
  1197. [Update on battery life: I wrote this review in May after using the shaver about 15 times without a recharge. Amazingly, I have not recharged the unit since my review and it's still going strong! I estimate that I have now enjoyed 30+ shaves without a recharge, with each shave lasting about 3 minutes. The buzzing sound is now a bit erratic, which I interpret as the charge finally wearing off, so I'm going to plug it in for a recharge.]<br /><br />This review is for the Model 9854L, given to me as a gift. (There are at least 4 different models that look quite similar and may, in fact, be variations of the same basic design. I make no claims about the other similar 3 models.)<br /><br />Bottom Line Up Front: This is a very capable beard trimmer with a very long battery life. It's comfortable to hold and has many attachments. Recommended.<br /><br />My usage pattern is to trim my beard about every 4 days. I keep it at a 2-week length, well above \\"stubble\\" length but still quite short (less than ¼ inch). (People have called it a \\"banker's beard\\".) I don't style it or do anything special - just zoom the trimmer along the grain of my beard using the #2 length guide, then work the trimmer against the grain to cut my mustache. I always use the full-size cutting head rather than bothering to swap it out for the ½ inch trimmer head.<br /><br />The trimmer is comfortably light, with just enough heft to feel solid but not enough to tire my hand. The rubberized handle is exceedingly sticky, making for a secure grip. There are 3 snap-on short-hair trimming guides - 5 lengths would have been better to cover all possibilities, but I make do with the #2 guide.<br /><br />There are several trimming heads that easily swap out. I always use the basic \\"full\\" trimming head, but there's a ½ inch fine trimmer (without any trimming guides, just the bare razor head) and another head for deburring neck hair. The different heads snap off and on easily as long as you remember to remove the trimming guides first.<br /><br />The retail package has the usual number of cheap combs and brushes. Nothing to write home about, but they do the job. And there's a stand on which you can mount all the components. Since I only use the trimmer, I just put everything in a drawer and forget about the stand.<br /><br />The lithium-ion battery life is astounding for a unit like this. I'm used to getting only 4 to 5 trims per charge from a typical battery operated beard trimmer. With this Wahl 9854L, I'm getting over 15 trims per charge and I've not yet let the battery run all the way down.<br /><br />What's not to like? As some others have mentioned, the rubberized handle is so sticky that facial hair clings tenaciously to it when you brush it or wipe it with a cloth. At first this bothered me a lot, even though I appreciated the safety value of the sticky handle. However, I discovered that the hairs come off quickly when I blow on them, so this is no longer an issue for me. [Update after 6 months of use: The stickyness wears off, leaving a very comfortable, non-slip grip. Still need to blow on the unit to get rid of the hairs, but it's not nearly as much of an issue as when it was new.]<br /><br />The razor makes quite a buzzing sound. Don't get me wrong, you don't need to wear ear protection when you use it, but the sound can be heard (albeit faintly) through a closed bathroom door.<br /><br />The power supply is small and light, but it's only 120V - a problem for me because I live in a dual-voltage house. If you decide to take this puppy on an overseas trip lasting less than a couple of months, just charge the trimmer and leave the power supply at home to prevent blowing it up when plugging it into a 220V outlet... or am I the only one who's ever done that?
  1198. This works great. I have a thick beard, and this helps out a lot with a very smooth trim/shave. The package contents are very useful. I am just unsure if I can wash this or not. I could not find information about that.

  1221. It blows away any competitors with which I have been familiar. Attachments are sufficient for most any user.<br /><br />This is the best. Highly recommended. Don't waste your time with inferior units.

  1223. Li-Ion devices generally boast great power capacities and this trimmer is no exception. I've used it three or four times a week for about eight months and it ran at full-power every time, right up to when the battery drain protection circuitry kicked in and shut it down, indicating that it was time for a recharge. 60 minutes on the charger and its ready to go for another eight months. My only gripe about the device is that the handle is wrapped in some rubber-like material that collects hairs like a magnet. It's not a big deal to wipe it down with a damp cloth, but I would prefer to be able to just brush it off without a fight.
  1224. Everything it was claimed to be!!
  1225. I bought this to use about once a week to shave my head and keep my goatee trimmed.   1234. I bought this unit for my husband for mostly beard and neck trimming. He has coarse beard hair and wears a beard or a goatee most of the time. Charging it only takes a few hours and you are good to go for several weeks.<br /><br />The attachments are great too. I like the way the tip are installed. Have had problems wit othe trimmers due to the attachment piece breaking making attachments wobbly and unusable.<br /><br />As an aside I have a cocker spaniel I groom and was having difficulty trimming around his feet and used this, worked so well I kept it for detail dog grooming and bought my husband a new one.<br /><br />Definitely worth the price.
  1235. As with many lithium ion batteries, the one in this shaver works for about two years and then will no longer hold a charge. When you open it up the battery is a 3.7v 750mah AA size, but it is soldered directly to the circuit board. It has a 5 year warranty so I would suggest returning it once the battery is dead.
  1236. I only had this product for 3 weeks and it completely stopped. I have charged it and cleaned it regularly but it won't turn on at all. I will be returning it for a refund.

  1241. Excellent battery life, with a very quick charge time. My only complaint is the clip-on guards are a little flimsy. All in all, I love mine.
  1242. This Wahl trimmer is small, lightweight, charges quickly, and does it's job well. It has lots of different attachments, more than most people would ever need or use but if you like choices, then this one is most certainly the winner! We are also given a stand with the trimmer, which honestly is too small to be useful but it is a thoughtful addition. My husband loved the ear trimmer and the shaver attachment which gave him a good close shave. He also uses this for those in-between haircut trimmings at the back of his neck and says he loves it! I took away one star for not having a charging indicator which isn't really needed, but the lack of it is very annoying since it is expected in such gadgets. Overall, we loved this little trimmer and would certainly recommend it at this price.
  1243. The Wahl Lithium Ion All In One Grooming Kit is a great product with adequate instructions. As a result, once I called the company and figured out how to use everything that came with the product I was very happy. I like this product because it comes with four easily changeable \\"blades\\" that can be attached to the base. The blades include a trim blade to use on beards and mustaches, a precision detailer to use on nose and ear hair as well as eyebrows, a dual shaver to use on faces if they do not have a beard and finally a clipper blade to use on the hair on one's head. All of the the blades work well. I also read in the instructions any of these blades can be used on other parts of one's body that are shaved or need to be shaved. This product also comes with seven guide combs that easily attach to the trimmer and can be used to help with grooming. Also included is a brush for cleaning the blades, a small comb, and some blade oil. All of these fit nicely into a stand. Finally, this product comes with a lithium ion rechargeable battery that charges in a shorter amount of time in comparison to regular batteries and keeps a charge longer as well. It also comes with a 5 year limited warranty. I am impressed with the number of uses for the grooming kit and like the idea of a lithium ion battery. Once charged up it does hold its charge well and is easy to recharge. All of the blades work well but I am still trying to figure out how the guide combs work. The reason I am still figuring out about the guide combs is because of the instructions. The instructions are on one piece of paper. The paper is folded in half and then has seven folds. In effect you have 14 squares that are 2 inches by 4 inches. The top half of the instructions tell about the warranty, things to do to keep safe, how to charge the battery and how to care for the trimmer. Since the instructions are the same for three different models one panel lists the other two models. The lastseven panels talk about the product. The type is smaller that that used on the safety instructions on the top panel and I found it a chore to read. One problem is since these instructions are for three models I could not figure out why my trimmer did not have a rotating head like it said in the instructions until I realized that the instructions were referencing a different model. There are some drawings that are somewhat helpful but they are small. I used the back of the box to figure out how some things work. I also called the company to figure out a couple of things. Had the instructions used larger type and diagrams like the back of the box I would have had an easier time understanding how everything worked. While the instructions are a bit of a problem they can't take away from how well this product works. The grooming kit is truly all in one and has many uses. I like the lithium ion battery. Ultimately, I am extremely pleased with the grooming kit and I recommend it.
  1244. Sleek, compact, sturdy trimmer. I really like how it handles, great percision. Great accessories, works well. light weight. Great quality.
  1245. I like that it is very durable, easy to clean, and has many different trimmers to choose from. Also, the battery lasts for a long time.
  1246. Well, I only used it once. It worked well and I like it. It has lots of attachments. Best of all - it was made in the USA.
  1247. worked great the first time. Second time to use it, spring came out of clipper head and will not work now. Very dissapointed in product. For the price this costs, you expect it to last a while.

  1258. Never again. Does not hold a charge. Some of the heads are difficult to replace and the adjustable head slips to a closer setting while you are trimming your beard. Oh well.
  1259. Almost every shaver out there is waterproof, except this one. Despite this huge shortcoming, WAHL never mentions it in the instructions or elsewhere that it's not waterproof. They just give you a cheap $0.05 brush that fell apart after 5 uses -- to clean the blades. A tiny bottle of baby oil (it seems) is also included to oil the blades after every use (but instructions said not to over oil, because the oil will seep into the motor and cause damage).<br /><br />So I did as instructed... I never washed it. I was inconvenienced and couldn't use it in the shower, but this was my first WAHL and I went with it, to give it chance. I oiled the blades every night. I cleaned them off after every use. Less than a month of use later, the main blade started rusting (despite never being washed). It got dull very quickly after the first week. You have to keep in mind that I do not have a thick beard at all. I maintain a very short goatee.<br /><br />The build quality of this is extremely cheap. It felt like a $5.00 shaver with chrome on it. The seam where the metal and rubber are joined had a fairly large & uneven gap and some glue was dried, seemingly having oozed out of the gap onto the rubber grip and dried on it's way here from China. The charger plug would wiggle back and forth when inserted into the shaver. There is no light or indicator anywhere letting the user know whether the shaver is charging or not, you just have to guess.<br /><br />The blades have large gaps in the sides so all your hair &#34;conveniently&#34; gathers inside the motor cavity and the intricate parts that move the blades, and the provided brush is too poorly designed to clean that out, so be prepared to vacuum it out.<br /><br />The shaver would lose charge after being left out for 5 days or so.<br />Finally, a whopping 60 days after I purchased this shaver, it stopped working. Dead. Zero. Charging it all night did not yield even 2 seconds of shaving.<br /><br />This was my first and last WAHL and Ihighly recommend that you DO NOT purchase this.<br />It says &#34;Made in USA&#34; on the box but the shaver itself was made in China.<br /><br />I just hope I can still get my money back, otherwise I don't mind throwing $35 in the trash.
  1260. I have used this same model of shaver for over 8 years. it lasts upwards of 3 years a piece! that's great for a cordless shaver.
  1261. As a male with a penchant for facial hair configurations that require constant upkeep, I have experienced my fair share of trimmers in this variety. I bought this with the intention of having a great quality trimmer for years to come. So far I have had this a month and have used all the attachments and blade guards.<br /><br />I find the Lithium Ion battery life to be spectacular thus far. The trimmer has only been charged one time but I have used it every other day since getting it. The attachments which were provided are all swapped out by removing the entire blade and snapping the other attachment firmly into place. The swap seems well-controlled, the pieces fit tight without anything feeling cheap or flimsy. The attachments themselves are all effective and high quality. They provide a great change for each.<br /><br />I bought this based on features, not on price, and still cannot believe the quality for the price! Came with so many pieces and has such a great, ergonomic style and battery life that I rate this a solid 5 from Wahl.

Granted, I only use it once or twice a week for 10 minutes, but none of the rechargeable clippers I've owned in the past even would have held a charge that long WITHOUT being used. As far as clipping goes, it does great and works very well for my needs. Has more accessories than you need (better than too few) and feels really nice and solid in the hand--not cheap--and the rubber grip is great. I assume this will die at some point down the road (they all do) but I'm going to order a second one in preparation for that day just in case they stop making this model. I've finally found the perfect beard trimmer (for me). There's really nothing I would change about it.

It gives like a day 4 stubble, where as i prefer it to be a bit more short. However, for those who want a slightly longer and prominent stubble this maybe the product for you. I recommend moving the shaver in the opposite direction of the hair growth for a better stubble look.<br /><br />The biggest issue with this product is that there is no charging indicator. When the product is plugged in there is no way to figure out of it's being charged or not. I kept it plugged into a faulty socket without realizing, and found out that the product had completely drained itself. How difficult is it to put in some LED bulb to indicate when charging?

  1290. I got this shaver after dealing with the frustration of a cheaper, Norelco shaver. The difference in price is more than made up for in convenience and quality.<br /><br />My main complaint about every other electric beard trimmer I've owned is battery life. The last one I had needed to charge for TEN HOURS to be used for 30 minutes! Inevitably, those shavers would sputter and die mid-shave at the worst possible times. I decided to upgrade to this highly-recommended shaver.<br /><br />What a difference the lithium-ion battery makes! Not only is the shaver visibly more powerful than the others I've used, but this charges in a fraction of the time it took for the others, and the charge lasts absurdly long. To make matters even BETTER, if you DO hit the end of your battery, charging this thing for ONE MINUTE gives you five minutes of trim time (enough to do a quick shave in a pinch).<br /><br />It feels good in your hand -- not too heavy and not too light -- and comes with a huge assortment of attachments. I would avoid using the blades they have for getting a close shave, as well as the nose-hair trimmer if you have other tools for that, but even those are really not bad. The classic and T-blades are just great, though. They also give you blade guards so you can cut at different lengths. Their 1/8 guard leaves just the right amount of stubble. This tool is also great at cleaning up my neck area as I grow a beard, easily defining lines and trimming well, without upsetting my sensitive skin.<br /><br />The only real downsides to this shaver are that it isn't waterproof (so no rinsing it off in the sink) and that the process to change blades is a little bit awkward. Still, these small concerns pale in comparison to the unit's virtues. It is certainly worth the money for this great tool.

  1300. My husband bought this in December 2013, but it cannot hold a charge more than about 10-15 seconds by September 2014. Researching in the web turned up ine era Le complaints of this exact problem.<br /><br />One other. It'd is that he bought this and it came with a plastic stand, not the carrying/storage bag, but otherwise, it appears to be identical.<br /><br />Whilst Wahl does offer a five year warrantee, they do not issue RMAs, so if you send it to them, and they lose it, tough, and also, when we called, we were told that the turn around time is about two to three weeks. Finally, and this is the nail in the coffin, though they have a long warrantee, they put the cost of return shipping on you, and the fact is, the quality of this product is so bad that it is just not worth the trouble.<br /><br />As for the product quality itself, there are several problems with this trimmer. Firstly, switch is sticky and difficult to turn on an off, the rubberised coating attracts any and all dirt and trimmed whiskers. The plastic blade guards are VERY flimsy, and the method for attaching the blades is really weird, so EVERYTIME he tries to hange them, he seems to have to fiddle with them for a minute to get them on. Other shavers and trimmers from other brands are simple pop-on, pop-off design.<br /><br />We used to think Wahl made the best quality clippers and trimmers, and maybe with their professional line products that may be the case, but for the consumer products, we feel they are just junk, and will try a different brand, and stick to a corded model. It just shouldn't be this much trouble for something so ridiculously simple as a trimmer.<br /><br />Incidentally, my husband only uses this for beard trimming. He uses the trimmer on his 6 year old Braun rechargeable electric shaver for his sideburns, and it still runs perfectly after all these years, though some of the paint did flake off near the head.
