  1324. I purchased the Wahl Lithium Ion trimmer because my old trimmer I had used for years was a Wahl.<br /><br />When I opened the box I discovered that the primary Trimmer head did not have a spring loaded vibrating mechanism like the other heads that would make that trimmer work.<br /><br />Well, that was a problem, but there was a larger T-Blade head that had all its parts and worked. The T-Blade head did not have an attachment with the 6 position trimming guide (like the primary Trimmer head) which would allow a variety of beard lengths. But, I only wanted a short stubble so the single short guide for the T-Blade was enough.<br /><br />I used the trimmer once and it worked pretty well. It provided a good result.<br /><br />The next time I tried to use it, it was dead, though I had it plugged in for several days and was, hopefully, charging it.<br /><br />Unfortunately, I misplaced my receipt and am now needing to purchase another trimmer.<br /><br />If you purchase this product make sure you keep your receipt so you can replace it.
  1325. This all in one trimmer comes as advertised and is the one-stop shaver i use to keep all my facial hair trimmed. I have had no issues with this trimmer and it it is easy to maintain and attach the various heads to the main device. The only complaint i do have is that i like a very close shave and the shave attachment does not give as great a shave compared to an old fashioned razor. However if you simply like your beard short and neatly trimmed this shaver does it for you with ease and let's you mark up your facial hair.
  1326. The hair trimmer kit from Wahl is an excellent choice in my opinion.<br />The main unit is light weight and designed to be very flexible, although it does not feel cheaply made. Also, I feel that it is nice to see that there is still something made in the USA.<br />The Lithium battery has an option for charging it just a few minutes, which forces just enough energy into it, to be able to do a quick trim.<br />I was impressed with all the optional items that can be attached.<br />The storage case is cheesy and cheap, I am glad it is only the storage tray.<br />At first I was scratching my head a few times before I was brave enough to remove the default cutting attachment.<br />I didn't want to break it and the pictorial instructions didn't make me too confident. But after a few times, it is actually quite easy.<br />I suppose, I am tending to make things more complicated as they really are.<br />Within the several attachments, one can choose one that is appropriate for the length of hair that needs to be cut. In my case I find it as easy as combing my hair, whats left of it.<br />I am very satisfied with the purchase and already amortized the cost of the device that I would have otherwise spent at the barber shop.
  1327. Powerful, lots of trimming options, holds a charge forever. One minor downside...beard trimmings seem to stick to handle. Buy it anyway!
  1328. Got this trimmer about 2 weeks ago, been using it about every other day so far. I needed a new trimmer after my old Wahl crapped out on me, and so far, I really like this trimmer. This definitely seems more powerful than my previous Wahl, allowing me to get an even trim on one pass over any given area. Despite the extra power, I don't feel like it's any louder, nor does it create any more uncomfortable vibration while shaving. It's also quite a bit lighter than my previous trimmer.<br /><br />Although it comes with attachments for cutting the hair on top of your head, I can't imagine this would really be strong enough for that job. I'm sure it could work...but I wouldn't want to let someone use it on my head. This is a beard trimmer. Those attachments are just there to boost the \\"usability value\\" of this product, not for actual use in my opinion.<br /><br />Despite what I read from another reviewer, I think the deatailer / nose hair attachment works quite well. It's narrow enough to get in your nose and snip those pesky hairs, so what more do you want from it? Switching between attachments is a breeze, so I'm not sure why some people find issue with that either.<br /><br />The foil shaver is great. I've always preferred a rotating head style for electric shavers, as foil shavers tend to pull hair out of your face rather than cut it. Maybe it's the power from the motor, but this foil shaver does a great job. I don't feel the tugging I'm used to from other foil shavers and I think it actually gives me a closer shave than my dedicated Norelco electric shaver (not trimmer like this). Still quicker to use the Norelco, but I really do think this foil shaver gets a little closer.<br /><br />So far, I've ran this out of power once, but it was intentional. I wanted to check the quick charge function. Sure enough, after only a minute of charging (after it was dead), I was able to run it for between 3-4 minutes. That is a great feature for those days where the battery dies onyou before work and you don't have the time to wait around for it to recharge so you can finish the job. After running it down from the quick charge, I charged it for an hour, since that's supposedly a full charge. Well, I've been using it every other day for a week and a half since and it hasn't died yet. So, I'm pretty pleased with the overall battery life. But, this brings me to my first issue. It has no light or anything to tell you when it's fully charged. All I ask for is a little LED or something that lights up or blinks when charged. But, no such luck with this trimmer.<br /><br />My other relatively minor issue is the tray for the attachments. I have no idea how they fit everything in the tray. I don't even have the haircut attachments in there, since I'm not ever using those, and I still can't fit everything in it nicely. It's just a small, cheap, plastic tray that doesn't serve much purchase. I appreciate the small size considering I keep this in the medicine cabinet, but still...if I can't really fit the pieces in it, what good is it?<br /><br />Summary: If you want a lightweight, powerful beard trimmer that won't leave you hanging with half a beard in the morning, this product from Wahl is an awesome buy. If you're looking to use this north of your ears and eyebrows, look elsewhere.
  1329. Hands down, this trimmer is super sharp. It does not seem to fail at all in the quality department. I did a few tests on both the \\"T-Trimmer\\" included, and the regular one, and both did superbly. I will, however, remind people that you have to use the included oil before using these blades. If you do not, you will not get much accomplished in terms of cutting your hair. It will still be sharp, but the blades will cut ten times better when you oil them up (While it's actually on). I am very impressed with this trimmer. I actually was not expecting to be so satisfied. I had looked all throughout the Amazon.com store, and was not satisfied with reviews of other products. If it wasn't overpriced, it was too cheap, and many of the reviews reflected that, but this appears to be the exception so far. I am satisfied. It has my mark. I am a very critical person when it comes to buying products. I am an avid Amazon.com customer (They have made a lot of money due to my loyalty to the site), so I like to investigate before buying. I ask you all that you do the same. Thanks, and enjoy your product.<br /><br />BTW, it works right out of the box. I didn't have to charge it before testing it.
  1330. This set is nice for the price and what you get, but the blade does not cut down close enough to your skin and does not leave your skin smooth (i.e., you get stubbles). It seems to 'look' okay, but it feels stubbly. Other than that, it's fine (but the point is to be smooth, too, right?) :)
  1331. I really loved this trimmer at first. I mainly just used it when my beard would come in thick or for the random body trimmings once in a while. I rarely used any of the other accessories that came with it but for the price it definitely did what I wanted.<br /><br />I normally don't review products but I really felt that I should, especially as someone who has owned this product for over 6 months. It dies. After 3 months I started to notice that it needed a lot more time to charge up and that it could only hold a full charge for one shave. After 6 months it worked for seconds at a time. Also, you can't just leave it plugged in and get away with it for two reasons. First and foremost, it still just doesn't charge the battery long enough and the electricity isn't a bypass. Two, the plug sucks and falls out if you try to leave it plugged in during use.<br /><br />So all-in-all. This thing is garbage... literally, as I just threw it out.
  1332. May 2016: Bought the second one a few weeks ago! The old one's main trimming head was getting loud, something wearing out in only that medium trimmer head (plastic bushings?). But 4.5 years is fair for the low price, used this trimmer head almost every day, the rest of the unit and attachments still work perfectly fine and the battery still works almost like new. Even the screen shaver attachment is still working good, and I used that about half of every day for the past 4.5 years too. The new package doesn't include the molded upright stand, instead it just has a fabric zipper pouch (don't care much). NOTE: The battery charges in 1 hour! Nov. 2011: I bought this bc my previous trimmers batteries went bad too quickly, and otherwise wore out. This new lithium-ion battery (the same type as in notebooks/netbooks/tablets, etc.) is MUCH better, lasts 3-10 times longer. I love how the accessories just snap on/off quickly. However it is not perfect: CONS: Comb (plain mustache comb) is VERY scratchy - almost dangerously so! I had trouble with the adjustable length trimmer &#34;comb&#34; (not the comb above). It did not want to move, &#34;adjust,&#34; at all. So finally with much force it did suddenly with an alarming crack sound, and now it moves too easily. I inspected it but cannot find any broken area. It must be held in place carefully while I trim to prevent making my beard too short. Screen shaver is very tricky to open to empty the trimmings, and there is no instructions on how to do so. Hair trimmings stick to 'sticky' rubber black handle area, under your grip. Switch is just a tad difficult to move at times. When changing accessories it is necessary to occasionally clean the hair shavings off of the driving areas, and they have grease on them - that's what the little brush is for. For those who complain about too many accessories: Really? Just throw them away then! The price is right. The big base makes it very stable and unlikely to be knocked over. Otherthan that, I love it, compared to multiple previous trimmers, mostly Wahl: PROS: It is excellent at trimming beards and mustaches. Can use it corded if the battery runs down. Very nice screen-shaver (screen shavers only work with short stubble). Accessories change quickly and easily. New batteries are great and long-lasting, last for at least a dozen trims (&#60;1yr old). New battery charger is very small and less of an eyesore. EDIT 12/4/13: After 1.5 years of use, I still love this shaver. Everything (except the adjustable-length trimmer comb) still works great, and the battery charge still works over multiple beard trims W/quick-trims in-between, and I am now using the screen shaver for my fully-shaven areas too on these quick-trims. I have used the oil several times. So great long-life too.

  1335. I purchased a Wahl 9854-600 Lithium Ion All In One Trimmer a couple months ago based on recommendations, and the company's reputation. I couldn't believe it when every use included pulled hair; sometimes only slight tugs and other times outright hurtful pulls. I have been using the trimmer head with the adjustable guide set on 4, sometimes 3. The fixed guides are too short.<br /><br />I kept looking at it and using it trying to determine why I was having trouble with it. Initially, I thought the problem may be with the adjustable guard.<br /><br />Unfortunately, I now believe the cutters do not accommodate thick hair. It is more of a shaver than a trimmer. If there was a way to include a photo it would tell the story. I placed the cutter head along side the one off my aging MB200 on a scanner and it's very apparent there is a big difference in how wide the teeth are. I think this is a nice quality machine and will be appreciated by anyone with thinner beard hair than I have.<br /><br />I've been meaning to get back to this for a while. I upped the rating to 4 because of the customer service. I did express my thoughts on the blade and did receive plenty of correspondence and a replacement blade to try. The new blade really did not help. I do stick to my initial observation; it is a quality machine and one of the few capable of trimming the mustache without folding your nose over or stretching your skin so the corner of your mouth touches your ear. But, I think the blade teeth are too fine to accommodate thick hair. You won't get better service, so you can't go wrong trying this one.ference in how wide the teeth are. I think this is a nice quality machine and will be appreciated by anyone with thinner beard hair than I have.

  1353. I've had about a half dozen trimmers over the past 20 years and this one was by far the best yet. I used it for everything from trimming the beard, shaving the beard, to shaving my head. The nose clipper head works perfect for your nose and the larger clipper head works pretty good for your head....The shaver head works ok...not great. I communicated with Wahl and requested a replacement which they provided without any hassle whatsoever, However the representative to whom I spoke pointed out that the part is considered &#34;disposable&#34;, thus it needs to be replaced just the same one would replace a razor blade.   1379. I had the older model, basically the same trimmer. Used it two to three times per week for at least five years. It had to have been over five years it lasted and it finally started to loose power and charge despite constantly being plugged-in. I started searching around for the advanced products I was sure might exist, but found nothing that compared in quality and design. Despite shopping around for some time and continuing to use my old model for facial and body grooming, I ended up purchasing the newer model with the Lithium battery. After several weeks of use I am so pleased with this trimmer. It's strong, powerful, and reliable. The only draw-back is the rubber handle, which is a magnet for small hairs and is difficult to clean. The older model had a similar rubber handle that seemed slightly easier to clean. Anyway, this trimmer is worth it's weight in gold and I would recommend it to anybody for beard and body hair. It has the utilities for trimming head hair, and I'm sure it's powerful enough for that.   1383. OK, I've used lots of hair cutters and have learned that there are somethings to be careful to look for:<br />1. Short cords - This doesn't have a cord at all, and the battery life is long, so it's a winner.<br />2. Stamped steel blades - Stamped steel blades don't last and they pull hair. These are machined; 'nother winner.<br />3. Noisy clippers don't last. Think about it; that noise, that hammering sound that you hear is something... hammering. The little clipper is beating itself to death somehow, and eventually, probably pretty soon, it will quit. This one is quiet for the win.<br /><br />The \\"organizer\\" that this set comes with is pretty useless, but only because it doesn't weigh anything. I turned mine over, filled it with BB shot (fishing aisle, Wal-Mart, $1.29) and topped it all off with Shoe Goo (also at Wal-Mart). Now the stand has a nice weight, and stays where I put it. I also got rid of the shaver attachment and the guards that I won't use (there really isn't room for EVERYTHING, so you have to choose what you will use). Now everything fits nice and neat.<br /><br />I've had this for about four months now, and it's the best all-rounder that I have come across.<br /><br />Update: I've been using this clipper once a week for a year, and it still looks and performs as new. It's also worth noting that this trimmer is easy to clean compared to other clippers that I've used in the past.<br /><br />Another update: Two years and going strong.
  1384. I used this Wahl trimmer for two years, on an average once a week for 5 minutes. After the first year, I started observing that the charge will not hold for more than a few minutes, steadily decreasing. For the last three months, the trimmer charge lasts under a minute after a full day of charging. Other review have described rusting and poor quality rubber grip, I agree. This is light trim, no heavy duty stuff here..<br /><br />Of course batteries degrade and die, some earlier than others. I took the trimmer to the repair shop indicated on the Walh website. Guess what, I found that this $45 trimmer is a throwaway item. I was quoted $40 llabor + cost of a new battery. The tech said the battery is not swappable, it is \\"hard wired\\"/soldered on.
  1385. An excellent trimmer, as far as how it cuts. BUT - this is a throw away piece, one in which Wahl did not intend the user to ever be able to change the battery! They seem to expect one to simply throw it away when the battery goes bad and buy another trimmer from them!! But, if you're a technically oriented person, the battery is available from Amazon: http://www.amazon.com/Cylindrical-Rechargeable-Batteries-Philips-Electric/dp/B00ML5K2OG/ref=sr_1_1?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1422152997&sr=1-1&keywords=3.7+volt+aa+battery+with+solder+tabs%27 Or, search the web for, 3.7 Volt Li-Ion battery, size 14500 (or AA) with solder tabs. It's available from most all battery dealers. The rubber skin covering the plastic case can be pealed back from the head to the tail, to remove it. Doing so will turn it inside out. When the work is done, it can be turned back right side out and pulled back over the body into place with a bit of effort. But, if you don't care about having a rubber grip, you might as well simply slice it off with a razor blade & forget about reusing it - your choice. Then, the case is easily pried open, using a small screwdriver. One will need circuit board repair & soldering skills to un-solder the old battery from the circuit board & to install the replacement battery, and minimal mechanical skills in order to reassemble the unit. If you're willing to do all of this, then it's a great trimmer! The only other issue I've had with it is the small trimming head began to work a bit intermittently, so I ordered a replacement from Wahl with no difficulties and at a reasonable price. However, Wahl has revealed itself to be a very consumer & environmentally unfriendly company with this design, as most folks will simply send a good piece of machinery, & a used up Li-Ion battery along with it, to their local landfill, simply because it needs a new battery!! I openly gave it 5 stars in hopes that more folks will see the review, but it really only deserves 2 or 3!

  1395. I had to return the first one after a week, because it died. I wish I would have exchanged it for the [[ASIN:B0058SY1XQ Wahl 9818 Lithium Ion Stainless Steel All-in-one Groomer]] ($50.99 Nov-2012). My second one lasted a few weeks (still on the first charge) and the on/off switch jammed. The internal sub-assembly seems to have come loose, so when I move the switch I am moving the internals instead. I waited too long to return it to Amazon, so I replaced it with the 9818. I wish that I would not have tried to save $20, because now I have paid $82 total.<br /><br />Other reviewers have mentioned the rubber cover and the hair that sticks to it. I wanted to return it for that reason before the switch stopped working. You cannot use water to rinse this off, and dry towels won't remove the hair. The thing that works the best is a damp rag, but what a pain. It picks up stuff on surfaces that appear to be perfectly clean. It's a magnet. If you don't mind the hair, or don't mind using a damp cloth, then this would not be an issue. But I would rather spend the extra $20 for the stainless version.<br /><br />I only use this to trim my sideburns, so all of the other attachments are a waste for me. I bought this because it was the least expensive Wahl I found with a lithium ion battery. The battery is amazing and neither trimmer worked long enough to need a recharge.<br /><br />Update Nov-2012: It was very nice to see the comment from Wahl (below). I have never had that happen before. I returned the defect and purchased the 9818. The 9818 was also apparently defective. The Wahl website says that both clippers have the same torque, but my new stainless 9818 runs slow and seems wimpy. After a full charge I could grab the blades while running and stop them using very moderate force. I was unable to stop the lesser expensive 9854 now matter how much force I used. I sent the 9818 to Wahl repair at the same time. They just received them today. I am sticking with Wahl in spite of thisexperience because they have the strongest motors, the best blades, and they are made in the USA. And now I know that their customer service is good too.

  1410. Does what you would expect. I have 2 main gripes. 1) As I suppose is a problem with quick change tip items, shaved hair gets into the mechanism and since the little shaft that does the work is in there and greased, it kind of gets messy. 2) You have to keep it on charge or it will discharge and the power supplied by the cable isn't enough to run the shaver with an empty battery. I use it once a week and if I unplug it, shave with it and forget to plug it back in, it will be dead on Monday when I need it again. Glad my remote control batteries on my TV don't do that.<br /><br />As with cordless circular saws, cordless weed eaters, cordless vacuum's, its probably better to just get the corded version unless you 'really' need that feature. This is no exception. Your likely using this in front of a mirror in a bathroom, there is likely an outlet right there. Why do you really need cordless? Of course, that is up to you. This product is ok. Not great, still kind of works, but I can tell its working harder than it should need to.

That'a about all I use. I like the size and heft of the device, it feels sturdy in my hand and is easy to maneuver.<br />The pouch is a bonus if you want to take this on the road. I was able to put the charger, trimmer and the attachments I use into the pouch and still have room.<br />It also seems to hold a charge very well. I used to keep the old one plugged in all the time, but with this one I just charge it once every couple of weeks. My only slight issue is the lack of a charging indicator. Normally there is a light that goes from red (charging) to green (charged), but for this trimmer you just plug it in and let it charge overnight. I'm not sure it is necessary or even very helpful since leaving it charge overnight seems to do the trick.

  1466. I'm a big fan of wahl products, they stay cool, have tight powerful motors, and have the sharpest ground blades.... Plus they are located right down the road in Sterling IL!<br /><br />With that being said I only rate this trimmer @ 3 1/2 stars<br /><br />Pros: powerful quality feeling motor, sharp close cutting blades, and easy interchangeable heads<br /><br />Cons: the foil shaving head sucks on any area other than the mid to upper cheeks. It pulls the hair, irritates my skin a bit, and leaves a spotty shave (some spots baby smooth and others with a 5 o'clock shadow). I have a beard so I only use it for upper cheeks and my neck area so I don't need a full size shaver, but this foil head just doesn't cut the mustard.<br /><br />The rubber handle is just too tacky. It's nice to have a rubber grip but just change the type of rubber so it can be brushed of instead of needing to be wiped down with a wet rag. It also attracts any dirt or dust it comes in contact with, which causes it to look dirty and dingy.<br /><br />Only other issue with it is the T-blade... It has a rough edge to it so it snags and nicks the skin vs gliding across it smoothly.<br /><br />The standard blade and small detail blade are excellent though with a close cut (as close as a trimmer like this can get anyway) and no snagging or nicks to the skin.<br /><br />I would buy again but if you're looking for a all in one trimmer with a good foil shaver I'd shop around

  1504. I've had quite a few trimmers over the years. I have a sensitive face, and don't like to shave every day, so between shaves I trim the stubble. All my past trimmers had several problems. They would occasionally pull hair instead of cutting it, the batteries wouldn't hold a charge very long, the charge they would hold would diminish over time, and the motors seemed to lose some power. Also, recommended charge time was typically 12 - 15 hours. Of course that's because all my old trimmers had NiMH batteries.<br /><br />Then I got the Wahl in December of 2011. It's lightweight, but you can really feel the power the first time you shave. No pulling hair, just a nice, clean cut. The first time you charge, they recommend charging for 1 hour. This thing holds a charge great, too. The Lithium Ion batteries are so much better! I see more trimmers offer the Lithium batteries than they did a year ago, but not many in this price range. I can't say just how long the batteries last, but they seem to go on forever. I keep thinking it must be ready to die soon, but it just keeps going. So it's easy to charge before it dies. Forget about 'battery memory' with Lithium, there isn't any. Any charge will do. You don't want to charge or discharge them too much, but Lithium batteries generally have built in safeguards against that happening.<br /><br />There are a few cons, but nothing worth taking off a star. Other trimmers offer &#34;lube for life&#34;, meaning you never have to oil the blades. You do need to oil the blades on this Wahl. However, it's pretty easy to put a drop or 2 of oil on the blades once a week, and it helps give a smooth shave. I have a feeling the the oil free trimmers might be more for planned obsolescence. Lubed for life, just a short life. The storage 'rack' is pretty cheap, and the pieces don't fit all that great. If you use it, don't bump it. I just keep my trimmer and accessories in a drawer cubby.<br /><br />I would definitely recommend this trimmer. If you need different features, at least try to find a lithium or a trimmer that also works off AC while plugged in.
  1505. It stopped working within a year. it did not hold the charge even when it was working. It is almost impossible to brush off the hairs from the body of the trimmer. I don't like paying for all of the combs and features that are not used.<br /><br />It does worked &#34;ok&#34; when it works. But the head needs to be wider for more coverage.
  1506. Quick charge, good power, nice attachments. It is working well...
  1507. I've been using this thing 2-3 times a week since I bought it, and it still works great!
  1508. After my faithful Wahl beard trimmer finally died after 20 years of good service, I decided I'd look for something that did more than just trim beards - I wanted a combination trimmer that would also double as an electric razor. This fails miserably at that task. At best, it'll make you look like you shaved 3 days ago. As a beard trimmer, it's great; but if I had it to do all over again, I'd have saved the money and just bought a trimmer. Again - if you're looking for an electric razor, look somewhere else. After years of trusting the Wahl name, I'm disappointed with this product.

  1513. i'm sincerely surprised to see so many well received reviews here.<br /><br />first of all, my razor came brand &#34;new&#34; from the store. i used it as soon as i got home, and found a mass of tiny hairs inside the original clip. i should have taken it back then, because this thing was clearly used in store or brought back because it didn't work and just put back on the shelf by the target employees, or used at some point in shipping.<br /><br />it's not the grossest thing in the world for sure, so i used it. thankfully i was able to shave to my satisfaction before the charge died, which wasn't long at all. i chalked it up to it obviously being used. the razor is also extremely loud and vibrates accordingly in the hand, not pleasant or comfortable at all.<br />i tried plugging it into the wall and turning it back on, but it does not bypass the battery charge. you have to use it charged only, and it takes much longer than a minute to charge a few seconds of use. why this was designed this way is beyond me. everyone has an outlet close to their bathroom mirror, you should be able to use the product plugged in or not, not solely on it's poor battery power.<br /><br />second time i used it, it wasn't cutting nearly as well, and i knew i didn't have much time before it died, so i had to apply more pressure to the skin and (which is of course my fault) cut myself. thankfully it was nothing visible and stopped bleeding after a minute, but i was right to hurry because it did die very quickly. very dissapointed. this isn't an item you want only sometimes working, especially if you need it for work, which was exactly the case.<br /><br />third time was the last straw. it was plugged into a working outlet over night, and never turned back on.<br /><br />this product is manufactured garbage, and came used when bought new in store.

This still seems to be the best trimmer I have found yet. Came in less than 36 hours from order time via Amazon Prime too. All-in-all I am very happy with this purchase.

  1531. I've been using this Wahl trimmer for about 3 weeks now, and it works just fine for what I need.<br /><br />In the past I have always &#34;clean-shaven&#34; my whole face, but recently I grew tired of shaving and decided to grow a simple &#34;Van Dyke&#34; just to see if I liked it. Turns out, as most people (besides me) could figure out, a Van Dyke or most any beard requires maintenance / regular trimming, or you end up looking like a homeless grizzly adams rather quickly.<br /><br />After doing lots of online shopping, I decided to take the plunge on this guy (Wahl Trimmer All-In-One Lithium Ion) as the price was right - I paid $24.95 at the time from Amazon.<br /><br />Trimming with this thing is easy for me, and I know nothing about beards or beard &#34;hygiene&#34;<br />The Wahl is perfect for cleaning up, trimming, and the little touch-ups I have to do every few days or so to keep from looking like a bum. I've tried (but rarely use) most of the accessories and additional trimming / clipping / shaving heads, etc - but the ones I have experimented with work just as well as the &#34;default&#34; trimmer head that comes attached.<br /><br />Works great not only for beards but for trimming just about anywhere, though I'm still too chicken to try the clipper blade for a self-clipped #2 haircut - I think I'll stick with a cost-cutters type vendor for those. But this kit works great for trimming just about everywhere else if you're not into gorilla-type body hair.<br /><br />One amazing thing - this trimmer arrived FULLY CHARGED - and I still haven't had to plug in the charger. The trimmer has been running just fine on a &#34;factory charge&#34; for 2-3 weeks now - (I am not making this up)<br />a testament to:<br />a) how little trimming I do with it<br />b) how incredibly well it holds a charge.<br /> - I would expect any battery-powered device to trickle / lose it's charge in a few days if not plugged in,<br />but this little guy just keeps crankin' like the Energizer bunny.<br /><br />The default trimmer blade that comes attached can sometimes be a little bit of work to re-attach after cleaning, but if I'm careful to line it up correctly and most importantly, NOT FORCE it back on, it's a minor issue. All the other heads and attachments seem to snap on and off just fine, as long as, again, they're not manhandled or forced on.<br /><br />Summary: All in all this was a great purchase - $24.95 for what imo is a decent trimmer that doesn't look or feel like cheap junk, and does exactly what I want it to do. I am completely satisfied with the product and price. I recommend it.
  1532. This unit works great.   1537. This is really the best all-in-one beard trimmer out there for this price and even better than some more expensive products out there. I've charge it once and used it at least 10 times or so on my thick beard, trimming my head hair, and on some body hair and it still doesn't need to be charged. The fine-toothed blades are also nice to keep you skin from getting as irritated if at all. The trimmer has plenty of accessories to cover multiple uses, and the shaving attachment actually works surprisingly well. It catches hair decently well and doesn't irritate my very sensitive skin on my neck. Even the expensive razors and shaving cream don't prevent the irritation on my neck, but this little attachment works. I like it.<br /><br />Here are the problems. First, the stand that this comes with is a joke. It's not even the one pictured on the box or in stock photos of the trimmer. It's terrible. It won't even hold all the accessories. The stand is super cheap quality. It's almost like they outsourced the stand production to another company that didn't even know what they were making it for. The rubber handle has so much &#34;stick&#34; to it that hair sometimes clings to it. It can be dusted off, but still, it's kind of annoying for a trimmer that isn't waterproof. And finally there's that. This would be the perfect trimmer if it was waterproof, but it's not. I would gladly pay more for this if it just had some type of water resistance...and a decent stand.<br /><br />All that said, it's a great trimmer and I recommend it despite its shortcomings, especially for the price.

  1545. This thing is very powerful, and loud when the battery is fully charged. My trick is to not keep it fully charged. When fully charged, it sounds like a low flying plane against your face, then as the battery drains switches to like a broken coffee grinder, further drain it continues to get quieter until it stops working, which is bad for the battery. So the trick is to charge it somewhere between the coffee grinder and stop.<br /><br />It comes with more attachments than I'll ever need. It's a shame my old wahl attachments don't work with it.<br /><br />Looks like price has dropped by 5 bucks since I bought it in aug 12.

  1564. Going for the record for longest owner review! I've had this wahl lithium trimmer for 4 years, and have been very pleased. I'm pretty picky and use it alot, about once a week, and i've been through many other types. this is the best i've found for me.<br /> First off, I'll tell you what I use it for: I shave my head often, I've used both heads with no guard and both short guards, all work well and cut at different lengths. and I trim my beard, usually short, the beard cutting head/guards work well, but i prefer to use the larger (wider) head, just because it goes faster. I also use the foil shaving head on my neck occasionally, and it seems great too. I haven't used this to cut any other types of hair so i can't comment on how it works for that.<br /> i've taken this trimmer to many different places i've lived, other countries, and even on a cross country bicycle trip (to keep me from looking like a total bum). the lithium power is really what makes it worth it, cuts quickly, and i don't have to always keep charging it.<br /> I eventually had a problem with it holding a charge after about 3 years. i was discouraged and thought it had finally bit the dust. i thought it was the battery so i sent it to wahl with the charger, and a few weeks later they returned it, I think with a new charger, under warranty, and it's been great ever since. Their customer service is very good. I recently called to order a new head that had been lost. I was on hold for 10-15 minutes, but the rep that answered was very helpful, knowledgeable and clearly communicated everything. I bought the head for 10 dollars and she sent me two guards for free.<br /> Biggest drawback for me has been keeping track of all the heads and guards. I've never been able to put them back in a back or container after i use them, and with a lot of traveling, I often misplace them in bags and eventually lost two guards. I wish there was a way to not need them, but i tried a new trimmer with fully adjustable one-piece head, and it worked terribly for very short haircuts (uneven). I did discover i can take a wire or paperclip and run it through holes in all the guards, that helps keep them together some.<br /> So, it's been a great item for me, serves its function well, and i don't have to worry about it. hopefully i can write another review after four more years.

  1567. I hardly ever write negative reviews -- I rarely need to -- but this product is so disappointing I want to let other shoppers know about it. I purchased this item because I remembered Wahl as one of the premier names in hair grooming products and I was replacing a much less elaborate Wahl trimmer that had given me more that ten years of good service. I initially noticed (as several other reviews have mentioned) that the accessories were EXTREMELY difficult to put on and off. Once I managed to attach a beard guide (not my first choice but the first one I was able to attach after three or four tries) and began shaving I noticed that the trimmed hairs stuck to the body of the unit. Not just attached but STUCK with the strength of velcro. Then I picked it up a few days ago and the blades ran rough and jerked my beard hairs instead of cutting them. I noticed a rattling sound so I removed the beard guide to clean the blades -- and some sort of clip fell out of the unit. But the rattling sound continues so I have no idea what else is floating around inside waiting to fall out. My bottom line: I purchased this unit 10/29/2014 and today is 3/6/2015 (just four months ago allowing for delivery time) and have used it lightly no more than once a week. There are some pros I could talk about and some more cons I could add but when a product stops working after four months the rest really doesn't matter. I have read the offers from Wahl to call and follow up on the warranty but honestly I have so little faith in this product and this company I don't think I would take a replacement at any price.

  1578. I didn't realize how long this little guy has been plugging away at the thankless task of managing my facial hair, but thanks to Amazon keeping track, I see that I've owned my Wahl Trimmer for just over three years. It's a pretty sweet little workhorse - always reliable and holds a good charge for a long time even after a long time on the shelf. I honestly can't remember the last time I charged it. I once let my beard grow, completely untamed for over six months. When it came time to prune it back, my Wahl was ready with a charge even though it sat, neglected, in my medicine cabinet for half a year. That's reliable.<br />Unfortunately, this past week I dropped my Wahl onto my bathroom sink from a height of just a few feet and the head popped off. I've been trying for days, but I've been unable to reassemble the spring and whatnot, and I'm usually pretty good at fixing such things. The user manual doesn't go into any detail about reassembling a dropped trimmer. I can't even find a YouTube video about putting this particular model back together. So it looks like I'm out of luck on this one, but it had a pretty good run until my own clumsiness did it in. Goodbye, faithful friend.

  1593. I bought mine 14 months ago (my first Wahl product and my first trimmer ever), and have used it about once a month since then, sometimes twice. I get my hair cut short monthly, and use this 2 weeks later to trim my neck hair, and once in a while for some manscaping. Before that I'd always used the trimmer on my electric razors.<br />I only use it for about 2-6 minutes at a time. Last week when I tried to trim my neck, the battery died before I could finish. I thought maybe it needed charging, so i plugged it in overnight. Next day as I finished my neck, the battery was running down again. I fully charged it, turned it on and timed it. I got 3 minutes 6 seconds until it was completely dead, and the last 45 seconds or so it was running so slow it would have been virtually unusable.<br />I have always fully charged it before each use since it had likely been sitting for weeks.<br /><br />So even if you figure 15 minutes a month over 14 months (worst possible scenario), that's only 4.5 hours of use and it's worn out.<br /><br />It did seem to work well while it lasted, rarely snagging hair, which is VERY important when manscaping! I tried using a depth attachment a couple times to trim my leg and chest hair (not thick at all), but found them fairly ineffective. I didn't find it to be excessively loud as others have complained about. My Braun razor [[ASIN:B003YJAZZE Braun Series 7-760cc Pulsonic Shaver System, Black and Silver]] is louder, my Norelco [[ASIN:B000PKNPES Philips Norelco arcitec 1050 Men's Shaver]] quieter.<br /><br />I found this response from Wahl on another review, so I'll call Wahl and see what they'll do about this defective item:<br />\\"We stand behind our product - we have a 5 Year Warranty and a \\"no hassle\\" customer service department ready to help fix whatever problem you may have. Wahl stands behind their product.\\"<br />I don't recall that it had a 5 year warranty - that's a long time. Unfortunately, there seem to be a huge number that don't make it past 1½ years. Meanwhile, my clock-radio that had a 1-year warranty has been going strong for more than 10 years.<br /><br />UPDATE: Called Wahl today and the lady offered to email a prepaid return label. When I asked if I could have a replacement sent immediately if I paid with a credit card, she said I could do that too, and return the old one after the new one arrived. This should have been offered as an option by the lady so I could receive a replacement faster, but it wasn't. I only knew to ask about that because of the response from a Wahl employee to another reviewer's issue. However I'm going to print the label and return the old one first anyway.<br />At least there was no quibbling about purchase date or proof of purchase. I asked if the battery had been upgraded, because there's a LOT of complaints about it, and she just said that improvements are made as the engineers feel is necessary, and she was unaware if the battery had been improved (Obviously not-see below).<br /><br />Update 12/3/14:<br />For the past few months the battery would only hold a charge for about 2 days. So that's 2 dead razors now due to battery problems in less than 3 years, and these are supposed to have a 5-year warranty. What a horrible joke! There should be a mandatory recall because owners of this model got screwed!<br />HEY WAHL, SEND ME A REPLACEMENT THAT WON'T DIE IN LESS THAN A YEAR! I DO NOT want another one of this model, or any other that uses the same or similar battery. Better change you warranty to 1 year, because your product often fails to even meet that!io that had a 1-year warranty has been going strong for more than 10 years. When I asked if I could have a replacement sent immediately if I paid with a credit card, she said I could do that too, and return the old one after the new one arrived.   1641. I purchased my trimmer on Tuesday, October 28, 2014 and received it on Thursday, October 30, 2014. I have used it every few days since then to trim my mustache. It was smooth, quiet and did the job well. I have used it once to trim my beard. It works just fine. However tonight, Tuesday, December 9, 2014 it started making a noise like, as one reviewer put it, a mini chain saw. I tightened the two screws on the blade but that did not fix the problem. I do not intend using it again. I had already purchased another trimmer for Christmas for my son. I'm dreading giving him that as a present since another reviewer has had a similar problem. I have used Wahl for years and was pleased with my last trimmer. It lasted 10 years. I like the lithium battery but am highly disappointed in having the trimmmer go on the fritz so soon after I purchased it. How can something with a 5 year warranty last only one month and a half? Had it not been for it suddenly becoming unusable I would have given this product 5 stars. One star is too high for a product only lasting one and a half months. Update on Jan 8, 2015. I finally figured what went wrong. The clipper insert broke. There is a metal piece (spring) on the back side of the clipper attachment which broke. I didn't have to unscrew the phillips head screws, I just needed to pull off the whole head. I noticed a metal piece on the bathroom counter, and it was from the attachment. I ordered the part from www.wahl-store.com and inserted it into the handle (the battery operated thing) and the clippers work great now. The part I ordered is WAH 59300-800. It's listed in the written material as part # 59300. I'm still upset that this clipper head broke after only 6 weeks, however the fix was relatively inexpensive. The part I ordered cost $7.50 plus $5.95 postage and handling. I ordered two and my total bill was $20.95. I'm not changing my rating since I have purchased a different brand clipper in the mean time. I just thought it appropriate to update my review. So, If the clipper ever sounds like a mini chain saw and doesn't clip well at all, it just might be the blade portion and a fix is relatively easy.

  1666. I had several criteria for this: it had to hold a charge for a long time, cut hair well, and had to be fun to use.<br /><br />I'm impressed with how long it has held a single charge...several weeks and counting. The motor is powerful and the blades are sharp. It is an excellent and precision trimmer.<br /><br /> It has a well-built feel, with a solid switch that turns it on and off. Just for fun, although I have a razor, I put the razor attachment on, shaved half my face, and used my Remington triple-head electric razor, which I also like a lot, on the other half of my face. The shaves were equally as close. So, the electric razor attachment shaves as close as a dedicated razor. The razor is more fun, though, and it is important that rituals such as shaving, hair trimming and the like should be fun. So, for ordinary use, the Wahl is just a trimmer.<br /><br />The only cons are that it does not have a light to indicated when it is fully charged. You just have to leave it plugged in an hour or two. Also, the instructions could stand to be a little clearer. But, in general, it's a fun and excellent trimmer to have around.
  1667. This Wahl product is definitely a lower construction standard than past Wahl products I have owned. The clipper has a cheap look, the base is light weight plastic of low quality. Recharging is inconvenient compared to past rechargeable Wahl trimmers. Instead of a recharging base unit that you set the trimmer into, you have to plug a small connector into the base of the unit and then set it on the stand while trying to ensure that the power cable doesn't knock out your accessory pieces. Looking at the materials and construction of the various attachments to the trimmer motor, it is easy to tell that they won't last long if used regularly.<br /><br />The first time I used it to trim my beard, it pulled on my whiskers several times. No other Wahl product I have owned has ever done that. I'm going to give it a chance to prove itself before going back to my other clipper and trimmer. For the money you should be able to find something better.
  1668. started out as a quality little trimmer, but failed after one year with very little usage. don't be fooled by all the accessories, not even Chewbacca would appreciate them as most are worthless. unreliable and too many pieces for me.
  1669. I was reluctant to buy an all-in-one product, but it is actually good. I'd had about three trimmers before. This one is a good basic trimmer as long as you take care of it (ground comb needs oil...) and it also is suitable for trimming a more creative cuts. (Anything from goatees to moustaches). Battery is strong and lithium. Get it with confidence.

  1676. Excellent shaver. Charged two months ago, still running.
  1677. I have purchased Wahl products in the past from hair trimmers to dog trimmers. The trimmer I have just purchased does a fantastic job trimming my beard. Heads are removeable and easy to clean by brushing the blade out. I sometimes blow the unit out with a bit of compressed air in a can. I use a blade lube with the product and to date it has done a fantastic job. It has a variety of different blades for styling your beard plus hair combs for further styling.<br /><br />I am buying each of my bearded sons a unit for Christmas. They will love it.

  1679. I've owned this trimmer for about 2 years and I've had no issues. The unit maintains its battery charge for a very long time. I use it exclusively for beard trimming and it works well. It is easy to clean with the included brush. The three heads simply snap on/off. Yes, you must keep the blades oiled. I like the caddy that is included - it holds all of the accessories and the razor - you can even 'dock' the razor while it is plugged in. For the price - really a 4.5+. More expensive razors are washable - that would be nice but those are typically 2 - 3 times more expensive. I have no regrets purchasing this product.

  1689. I will first say that, performance-wise, this is a 5-star trimmer. But considering the product as a whole, I couldn't give more than 4 stars, and would have given 3 1/2 if it was allowed. Read on to find out why.<br /><br />I've been using this since early January. I got it to replace my Norelco [[ASIN:B0016BN4YQ Philips Norelco G480 All-in-One Premium Grooming Kit]] trimmer that refused to charge after about 3 years. The Wahl is has noticeably more power and is quieter. The extra power translates into quicker and cleaner cuts for beard trimming. It has both a small and large blade set, but I don't see that I'll ever use the large blade. This is good because there is no place on the stand for it. I've managed to place all the attachments except this one on the poorly designed stand; instead it resides in a Ziploc bag in one of the bathroom drawers. Maybe it's just me, but if you're providing accessories, you should provide proper storage for them as well. That's a 1/4-star deduction.<br /><br />As a man in his later mid-life who wants to maintain a well-groomed appearance, I find regular trimming of nose and ear hair (I know - gross) is very important to me. So I was disappointed to find that a circular trimmer was not included. Not only does this product not have this cutting attachment, it doesn't even accommodate this particular accessory. (The attachment of this type offered by Wahl does not fit this model trimmer.) So much for the \\"All-in-One\\" billing. That's a 1/2-star deduction.<br /><br />The fact that I have to spend more money on a separate \\"nose/ear\\" trimmer is another 1/4-star deduction. A company like Wahl should have paid attention to small details such as these (it's what once made them great); instead they seem to be relying solely on their reputation and good name. (Maybe they should provide \\"complete\\" products as advertised and not rest on their laurels.)

  1712. I purchased my trimmer in July of 2012, and use it primarily for stubble-length trimming of my beard and mustache. It has worked well and initially the charge lasted for several trims, so I had confidently carried it with me on business trips without the charger. About 10 months after I purchased it, the trimmer started dying before I was able to finish a single trim. I thought that it would carry me through a single trimming if I just started with it plugged into the charger - wrong... Here at the 11th month, it won't even make it through a single beard trim (~7 minutes) even when starting with it plugged into the charger.<br /><br />It has a 5 year warranty, so be sure to save your manual/guarantee & receipts!
  1713. I got this for my boyfriend as an anniversary present. I read the reviews and they stated that it does a decent job with thick hair, so I figured it'd work well with my boyfriend's beard. The boyfriend tried it out as soon as I got it for him and he seemed pleased with the results. He tried to use the dual shaver to no avail, but he never really had success with them in the past anyway. His only complaint was that the handle of the trimmer was a bit sticky and all the shaved hair would stick to it, but all in all he was pleased.
  1714. The Wahl trimmer works just as advertised. The trimmer comes with a large selection of adapters. The best part is the lithium ion battery. It keeps a charge for a long time and recharges fairly quickly.
